description:
The Intel Xeon 6745P is a server/workstation processor with 32 cores, launched in February 2025, at an MSRP of $5250. It is part of the Xeon 6 lineup, using the Granite Rapids-SP architecture with Socket 4710. Thanks to Intel Hyper-Threading the core-count is effectively doubled, to 64 threads. To further increase overall system performance, up to two Xeon 6745P CPUs can work together in a multi-processor (SMP) configuration. Xeon 6745P has 336 MB of L3 cache and operates at 3.1 GHz by default, but can boost up to 4.3 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6745P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6745P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 300 W, the Xeon 6745P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the system, Xeon 6745P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6745P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.

Xeon 6760P has 320 MB of L3 cache and operates at 2.2 GHz by default, but can boost up to 3.8 GHz, depending on the workload. Intel is making the Xeon 6760P on a 5 nm production node, the transistor count is unknown. The multiplier is locked on Xeon 6760P, which limits its overclocking potential.
With a TDP of 330 W, the Xeon 6760P is extremely power hungry, which means you need top-notch cooling. Intel's processor supports DDR5 memory with an eight-channel interface. The highest officially supported memory speed is 6400 MT/s. ECC memory is supported, too, which is an important capability for mission-critical systems, to avoid data corruption. For communication with other components in the machine, Xeon 6760P uses a PCI-Express Gen 5 connection. This processor lacks integrated graphics, you might need a graphics card.
Hardware virtualization is available on the Xeon 6760P, which greatly improves virtual machine performance. Additionally, IOMMU virtualization (PCI passthrough) is supported, so that guest virtual machines may directly use host hardware. Programs using Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX) can run on this processor, boosting performance for calculation-heavy applications. Besides AVX, Intel has added support for the newer AVX2 and AVX-512 instructions, too.
